image.altText: Ross Fox wearing a dark business suit, sitting at a small with four energetic school students writing in their notepads.

items.synopsis: Universities will be given two years to overhaul their education degrees or risk losing their accreditation as part of a national bid to fix Australia's teacher shortage.

title.children: Dissatisfied with university teaching degrees, Ross retrained more than 1,000 teachers. The results were huge

image.altText: Two Year 12 students use laptops at John Paul College.

items.synopsis: Mobile phones and smart watches will be banned from all state schools, in a move to bring Queensland's policy in line with the rest of the country.

title.children: Mobile phones and smart watches to be banned in all Queensland state schools, government confirms

image.altText: Commissioner Catherine Holmes, ex pm Scott Morrison, ex ministers Alan Tudge and Stuart Robert, bureaucrat Kathryn Campbell

items.synopsis: Commissioner Catherine Holmes faced the unenviable task of reviewing about a million tendered documents and hundreds of hours of evidence over nine weeks of public hearings. Follow live.

title.children: The final report into the disastrous Robodebt scheme will be released today. Here's what we know

image.altText: Mitch Marsh and Pat Cummins complete a high five in celebration of a wicket

items.synopsis: Australia takes three wickets late on day one at Headingley after Mitch Marsh's blistering 118 carries the side from the brink of disaster to respectability in the third Test.

title.children: Late wickets and Mitch Marsh's brilliance rescue Australia from disastrous day one at Headingley

image.altText: Mitch Marsh closes his eyes as he holds his bat and helmet up

items.synopsis: It came out of nowhere and ended just as abruptly, but Mitch Marsh's incredible century proved critical on a day that England found new Ashes life in some Mark Wood thunderbolts.

title.children: Mitch Marsh's magnificent fever dream keeps Australia alive on rollicking day one at Headingley

image.altText: Torn pieces of paper forming the head shoulders and obscured faces of a doctor with a face mask and stethoscope

items.synopsis: Almost 730 registered health professionals were accused of inappropriate behaviour or sexual misconduct by patients in the last financial year, new figures reveal.

title.children: Doctors, nurses investigated amid 'distressing' surge in sexual misconduct against patients

image.altText: A close up of a man leaning against a helicipter while wearing fatigues and protective equipment

items.synopsis: Baruch's only son was suddenly killed in military action. Now he's fighting for permission to use his son's sperm to create a grandchild.

title.children: Hours after his son died, Baruch had a plan to extract his sperm and keep his grandparenting dreams alive

image.altText: A middle-aged Indigenous woman with long dark hair stands behind a lectern filled with microphones.

items.synopsis: Earlier, the government was putting much faith in "the vibe" to carry the Voice – a general appeal to righting the wrongs of the past and giving Indigenous people the opportunity to be heard. Now the government is desperate to arrest the slide, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: The new 'prime target' in government's battle to stop the slide in Yes vote

image.altText: A group of New Zealand Maori men, dressed in soccer uniforms, perform the haka

items.synopsis: First Nations footballers from the neighbouring countries have been competing in a series of games ahead of the FIFA World Cup. They hope it'll lead to an Indigenous competition on the global stage.

title.children: Australia and New Zealand First Nations footballers hope historic series will lead to Indigenous World Cup

image.altText: Plants in a cylinder-like chamber.

items.synopsis: The scientists behind the project are aiming to grow plants on the lunar surface within four years, something they hope will in turn allow for the development of food, medicine and oxygen in the hostile environment.

title.children: Australian start-up aiming to grow plants on the Moon receives $3.6m in government funding

image.altText: Liam Broady puts his hands to his ears on Centre Court at Wimbledon

items.synopsis: Stan Wawrinka set up what looms as a potentially epic showdown with Novak Djokovic and Australia's men recorded a trifecta of victories but the day belonged to the most unlikely of local British heroes as Centre Court erupted for a massive upset.

title.children: Murray mound? Make it Broady's boulder. Wimbledon erupts as local hope records huge upset on Centre Court

image.altText: A missing person poster of a Hispanic teenage boy, showing his name and a table with descriptive information.

items.synopsis: A few days after Rudolph "Rudy" Farias IV was found unconscious outside a Houston church, police say he and his mother had spent eight years maintaining the ruse he was a missing person.

title.children: 'Missing' man Rudy Farias spent eight years with his mother hiding his existence

image.altText: A set of shelves with papers and a collection of wigs laid out on them.

items.synopsis: Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko, who last month brokered a deal to end an armed mutiny in Russia, says Russian mercenary leader Yevgeny Prigozhin is no longer in Belarus.

title.children: Prigozhin is not in Belarus, Lukashenko says, as Moscow shows off wigs, guns and fake ID from Wagner boss's home

image.altText: A young Indigenous man skydiving with a young woman. The man is smiling and gesturing to Uluru, pictured below.

items.synopsis: Skydiving isn't always how Marley imagined he'd get his kicks, but ever since he was a kid, he's been chasing the thrill.

title.children: Marley's search for excitement could have put him behind bars. Then he found a way to harness the high

image.altText: Jilkminggan community

items.synopsis: Police say a woman has died after being stabbed in the back in Jilkminggan community, south-east of Katherine.

title.children: Woman dies after being stabbed by man in remote NT community, police say

image.altText: Ice in the ocean

items.synopsis: Over the past few weeks, climate records have shattered across the globe. So what's going on with the climate, and why are we seeing all these records tumbling at once? asks Kimberley Reid.

title.children: Why are so many climate records breaking all at once?

image.altText: A teenager in Balgo poses with her hands in piece signs near the dam.

items.synopsis: Last summer, feuding between different groups in the Western Desert town of Balgo saw brawls break out in the streets. But an innovative new youth program has helped turn things around.

title.children: How a town lowered burglary and theft by 75 per cent

image.altText: Stacey Mason during her training as a CQUniversity student.

items.synopsis: Stacey Mason has just had a kidney transplant. It's made her more determined than ever to pursue nursing.

title.children: Nursing graduate Stacey was recovering from a kidney transplant when named vocational student of the year

image.altText: A composite of three images: Anthony Albanese smiling in a suit, Margot Robbie smiling, and Ash Barty smiling

items.synopsis: It's time to test your knowledge of the week that was.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: From Barbie to the Taliban, and drugs in the White House

image.altText: England captain Ben Stokes puts his arm around an angry Joe Root in the field during an Ashes Test.

items.synopsis: Joe Root and Jonny Bairstow dropped crucial chances for England as Mitch Marsh capitalised and Mark Wood hit top speed on his return. Here are the five things you missed overnight on day one of the third Ashes Test at Headingley.

title.children: Five quick hits — Sloppy fielding costs England dear as two players make triumphant Test returns

image.altText: The ASX close to steady in early trade as seen on the exchange's board at its Sydney office

items.synopsis: The ASX is set to follow Wall Street's lead and dive at the start of the trading day, after strong labour market data out of the US increased the likelihood of a Federal Reserve rate hike to curb inflation. Follow live.

title.children: Rate hike fears cause sharp losses on Wall Street after resilient US labour data, ASX set to plunge

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I know what you're thinking — Birkenstocks and a finance blog are oil and water — but stick with me here. Reports from Bloomberg suggest that a private equity firm backed by the parent company that owns the German sandal maker is considering strategic options — and that includes an initial public offering (or IPO, if you're up with the lingo). L Catterton, which is a private equity firm backed by LVMH (a mammoth corporation behind major luxury brands), is working with advisers on potentially listing Birkenstock in the US. Discussions are ongoing, and the deal may not proceed, but Bloomberg's reporting suggests Birkenstock could be valued at more than $US6 billion ($9 billion). Birkenstock sold a majority stake to L Catterton in 2021, with the deal at the time valuing the sandal maker at $US4.35 billion ($6.5 billion). L Catterton has declined to comment on the reports, and at the time of writing this, LVMH and Birkenstock haven't responded to requests for comment from Reuters.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Birkenstock valued at more than $9 billion ahead of possible IPO

children.content: I know what you're thinking — Birkenstocks and a finance blog are oil and water — but stick with me here.

Reports from Bloomberg suggest that a private equity firm backed by the parent company that owns the German sandal maker is considering strategic options — and that includes an initial public offering (or IPO, if you're up with the lingo).
L Catterton
, which is a private equity firm backed by LVMH (a mammoth corporation behind major luxury brands), is working with advisers on
potentially listing Birkenstock
in the US.
Discussions are ongoing, and the deal may not proceed, but Bloomberg's reporting suggests
Birkenstock could be valued at more than $US6 billion
($9 billion).
Birkenstock sold a majority stake to L Catterton in 2021, with the deal at the time valuing the sandal maker at $US4.35 billion ($6.5 billion).
L Catterton has declined to comment on the reports, and at the time of writing this, LVMH and Birkenstock haven't responded to requests for comment from Reuters.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: News outlet Semafor is reporting that Twitter has threatened to sue Meta over its new social media platform, Threads. After launching a day ago, more than 30 million users have signed up to Threads — including our PM Anthony Albanese — which is set to rival Elon Musk's Twitter. Semafor's report cited a letter sent to Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg by Twitter's lawyer Alex Spiro, which accused Meta of hiring ex-Twitter employees. The report says those Twitter employees "had and continue to have access to Twitter's trade secrets and other highly confidential information". "Twitter intends to strictly enforce its intellectual property rights, and demands that Meta take immediate steps to stop using any Twitter trade secrets or other highly confidential information," Spiro wrote in the letter. But that suggestion has been dismissed by Meta spokesperson Andy Stone, in a statement posted to Threads (of course). "No one on the Threads engineering team is a former Twitter employee — that’s just not a thing," he said. So what's Elon Musk's response been? I'll let this tweet speak for itself. While we're on this topic, were you one of the 30 million early adopters who signed up for Threads yesterday, or are you selective with your social media platforms? Let me know your thoughts using the blue comment button at the top of the blog.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Could Twitter be about to sue Meta over Threads?

children.content: News outlet Semafor is reporting that
Twitter has threatened to sue Meta
over its new social media platform, Threads.
After launching a day ago, more than 30 million users have signed up to Threads —
including our PM Anthony Albanese
— which is set to rival Elon Musk's Twitter.
Semafor's report cited a letter sent to Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg by Twitter's lawyer Alex Spiro, which
accused Meta of hiring ex-Twitter employees
The report says those Twitter employees "had and continue to have access to Twitter's trade secrets and other highly confidential information".

"Twitter intends to strictly enforce its intellectual property rights, and demands that Meta take immediate steps to stop using any Twitter trade secrets or other highly confidential information," Spiro wrote in the letter.
But that suggestion has been
dismissed by Meta spokesperson
Andy Stone
in a statement posted to Threads (of course).
"No one on the Threads engineering team is a former Twitter employee — that’s just not a thing," he said.
So what's Elon Musk's response been? I'll let this tweet speak for itself.
While we're on this topic, were you one of the 30 million early adopters who signed up for Threads yesterday, or are you selective with your social media platforms?
Let me know your thoughts using the blue comment button at the top of the blog.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, it's Friday July 7 and you're reading the ABC's business and markets live blog. Let's cut right to the chase — overnight, Wall Street's big three indices all finished lower, stoked by market fears another rate hike is on the way. Although those fears have been hovering around all week, investors are jittery after US labour market data showed there was only a moderate increase to the number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits, all the while private payrolls rose. That points to a labour market that remains on steady footing, despite the growing risks of a recession in the US. Not only that, but the report suggested that those workers who were recently laid off aren't remaining unemployed for long — they're finding new work in a shorter time frame. The data also showed more people are quitting their jobs, which is a telltale sign of confidence in the labour market. The upshot? It makes it all the more likely the Federal Reserve will lift interest rates at its meeting this month, after pressing the pause button in June. But the data doesn't stop there — the full US employment report drops tonight. Back home, the ASX is looking unlikely to recoup its losses from trading yesterday. Futures are down, and based on Wall Street's drops from overnight, things aren't looking too rosy for the local market. Grab a coffee, settle in, and let's see how the trading day unfolds.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX set to plunge after Wall Street dives on rate hike fears

children.content: Good morning, it's
Friday July 7
and you're reading the ABC's business and markets live blog.
Let's cut right to the chase — overnight, Wall Street's big three indices all finished lower, stoked by market fears another rate hike is on the way.
Although those fears have been hovering around all week, investors are jittery after US labour market data showed there was
only a moderate increase to the number of Americans filing for unemployment
benefits, all the while private payrolls rose.
That points to a labour market that remains on steady footing, despite the growing risks of a recession in the US.
Not only that, but the report suggested that those workers who were recently laid off aren't remaining unemployed for long — they're finding new work in a shorter time frame. The data also showed
more people are quitting their jobs
, which is a telltale sign of confidence in the labour market.
The upshot? It makes it
all the more likely the Federal Reserve will lift interest rates at its meeting this month
, after pressing the pause button in June.
But the data doesn't stop there — the full US employment report drops tonight.

Back home, the ASX is looking unlikely to recoup its losses from trading yesterday. Futures are down, and based on Wall Street's drops from overnight, things aren't looking too rosy for the local market.
Grab a coffee, settle in, and let's see how the trading day unfolds.

image.altText: A snow covered ski resort with people walking around in padded clothes

items.synopsis: Light snow started falling on Thursday afternoon and should continue through Friday, before increasing at the weekend when a powerful cold front crosses south-east Australia.

image.altText: A woman dances with four children wearing orange and traditional skirts.

title.children: Titanic sub operator suspends expeditions after deadly implosion

image.altText: Tony Abbott sits in a chair with his hands in his lap.

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Tony Abbott says a constitutionally enshrined Voice to Parliament is "wrong in principle" and will reinforce "separatism" in Australia.

title.children: Voice to Parliament 'damaging in the long term', former PM Tony Abbott says

image.altText: A finger supports the head of an unconscious sugar glider which is lying on a surgical cloth.

items.synopsis: After three years of operation and more than 4,000 animal patients, the Byron Bay Wildlife Hospital fears it may close after the state government withdrew a funding offer.

title.children: Last-minute funding backflip a 'bitter pill to swallow' for Byron Bay Wildlife Hospital

image.altText: A kangaroo hops through the inside of a country style pub

items.synopsis: Farmers in NSW's west say they haven't seen numbers like these since the early years of the last drought, but long-term data tells the population has halved over 20 years.

image.altText: Graphic showing AFL stadium at Mac Point superimposed over historic goods shed which is in the same spot

items.synopsis: A historic goods shed in Hobart that's in the exact spot of a proposed AFL stadium could soon be given heritage protection — and that could be a problem for the arena project.

image.altText: A group of women with microphones dancing on stage

image.altText: Elderly woman turns her eyes to the side to look at camera with bandana on head

image.altText: Jai Hindley looks down

items.synopsis: A Gold Coast dad says his sons are beside themselves as a result of the "disgusting" crime. The family's car was also stolen and their house was trashed.

title.children: Bowie the blind dog, stolen from Gold Coast home, caught on camera at interstate servo
